conversation.content: [confused] Eight years. Um, I just opened the journal and there it is—her name, her photo, my... [pause] wait, that's literally my graph. That's my—hold on, [angry] are you kidding me right now? She used the exact same, I mean, the biomarker panels are identical to what I've been... [bitter] Oh how convenient, Dr. Patterson suddenly has a breakthrough. [frustrated] You know what's funny? Last month she was asking me all these questions about, uh, progesterone timing and I thought she was just being collegial, but now—[very quietly] God, I'm such an idiot. [laugh] She even used my color coding system! [sarcastic] Very original, Patricia. Really groundbreaking work there. [shaky voice] The thing is, I trusted her. We had coffee every Tuesday and she'd sit there listening to me talk about my protocols and, like, taking her little notes and I thought—[very sad] I actually thought we were friends. [clearing throat] Anyway, here's what I'm gonna do. I have every single lab report timestamped, every IRB approval, basically years of documentation that proves... [upset] It's just that nobody's going to care, are they? She published first. That's all that matters. [slowly] Eight years of my life, and she gets the Nature paper.

subject: Your reproductive endocrinologist colleague just published the fertility breakthrough you've been researching for eight years using data suspiciously similar to yours
